A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Quantum dots Schottky junction Surface plasmon resonance Visible light absorption Sensitizer Co-catalyst Hydrogen production
A B S T R A C T
Nano-size photocatalysts exhibit multifunctional properties that opened the door for improved efficiency in energy, environment, and health care applications. Among the diversity of catalyst Quantum dots are a class of nanomaterials having a particle size between 2 and 10 nm, showing unique optoelectrical properties that are limited to some of the metal, metal oxide, metal chalcogenides, and carbon-based nanostructures. These unique characteristics arise from either pristine or binary/ternary composites where noble metal/metal oxide/metal chalcogenide/carbon quantum dots are anchored on the surface of semiconductor photocatalyst. It emphasized that properties, as well as performance of photocatalytic materials, are greatly influenced by the choice of synthesis methods and experimental conditions. Among the chemical methods, photo-deposition, precipitation, and chemical reduction, are the three most influential synthesis approaches. Further, two types of quantum dots namely metal based and carbon-based materials have been highlighted. Based on the optical, electrical and surface properties, quantum dots based photocatalysts have been divided into three categories namely (a) photocatalyst (b) co-catalyst and (c) photo-sensitizer. They showed enhanced photocatalytic performance for hydrogen production under visible/UV–visible light irradiation. Often, pristine metal chalcogenides as well as metal/metal oxide/carbon quantum dots attached to a semiconductor particle exhibit enhanced the photocatalytic activity for hydrogen production through absorption of visible light. Alternatively, noble metal quantum dots, which provide plenty of defects/active sites facilitate continuous hydrogen production. For instance, production of hydrogen in the presence of sacrificial agents using metal chalcogenides, metal oxides, and coinage metals based catalysts such as CdS/MoS2 (99,000 μmol h−1g−1) TiO2–Ni(OH)2 (47,195 μmol h−1g−1) and Cu/Ag–TiO2 nanotubes (56,167 μmol h−1g−1) have been reported. Among the carbon-based nanostructures, graphitic C3N4 and carbon quantum dots composites displayed enhanced hydrogen gas (116.1 μmol h−1) production via overall water splitting. This review accounts recent findings on various chemical approaches used for quantum dots synthesis and their improved materials properties leading to enhanced hydrogen production particularly under visible light irradiation. Finally, the avenue to improve quantum efficiency further is proposed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Hydrogen (H2) is a cleaner fuel, that can be stored in gas cylinders for several months and conveniently transported from one to other places, hence it is ranked as an alternative fuel to fulfill the present and future energy demand.1, 2 It has a high energy content which is 2.6- times higher than gasoline and eco-friendly compared to gases emitted by fossil fuels combustion. The H2 gas can be used for various fields such as the production of chemicals (ammonia), fuel for automobile and rockets, power generation, antioxidant, reducing agent in chemical reaction and gas balloon for environmental monitoring. Commercial steam reforming process is the primary source of H2 production from chemical industries which is quite expensive and requires high thermal energy for operation. Hence water splitting by one of the following three processes namely photocatalysis, photo-electrochemical and photo-biological, has been identified as a renewable, sustainable and cleaner process for hydrogen production. Among these, photocatalytic water splitting is witnessed as an uncomplicated process, as it utilizes renewable solar energy and water.
Numerous photocatalysts have been prepared using different concepts/methods that can facilitate cleaner H2 generation via water splitting process. However, industrial scale-up approach is hampered by low quantum efficiency of the catalysts due to one or the other reasons: (a) utilization of a narrow range of solar light and (b) rapid recombination of excitons (c) poor surface reactions. Quantum Dots(QDs) based composite catalysts are considered to be a viable solution to address these issues. They are zero-dimensional nanocrystals with a physical dimension smaller than the excitons Bohr radius. QDs of carbon, silicon, bismuth, and noble metals have been synthesized by various methods in previous reports (Apte et al., 2013; Kang et al., 2008; Zhao et al., 2016). QDs such as colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals of 2–10 nm size may contain 10-50 atoms within the quantum volume (Murphy, 2002). So far a good number of reviews have been published on synthesis methods, characterization, surface chemistry, nature of capping agents and optoelectronic properties of quantum dots (Hines and Kamat, 2014; Kershaw et al., 2013; Liu and Su, 2014). Recently Kandi et al. (2017), consolidated the importance and role of quantum dots on photocatalytic hydrogen production. Literature on this topic can be categorized as follows: Choice of synthesis method, nature of precursors/surfactant, reducing/precipitating agent, reaction conditions which bring out unique properties and diverse applications(Hines and Kamat, 2014; Kershaw et al., 2013; Liu and Su, 2014).
The important reason for selecting quantum dots for enhanced H2 production compared to other types of nanomaterials is that they possess exceptional properties that are beneficial to improve the photocatalytic activity. Some of the important properties of QDs are,
a. Absorption of light in the visible region b. Multiple excitons generation due to quantum confinement. They are
able to emit up to three electrons per photon of solar radiation absorbed whereas it is only one electron in the case of bulk semiconductor materials
c. Better charge separation and transport d. Quantum confinement effect and large intrinsic dipole moment e. The high value of excitons co-efficient in the visible region of the
solar spectrum f. Luminescent properties g. Visible light absorption when doped with wide bandgap semi-
conductors
These exceptional properties make quantum dots as a special type of nano-materials for photocatalytic applications as shown in Fig. 1, and hence they become a hot topic of research in this field.
In this article, we reviewed the new developments in chemical methods used for the preparation of various types of QDs based on hybrid systems comprises of metal oxides, metal nitrides, ternary
composites and morphologically different, 1-D, 2-D nanomaterials. Further, we discussed physicochemical properties, band-gap characteristics, control of size and morphological structures, parameters influencing catalytic efficiency, catalytic mechanism focusing mainly on solar photocatalytic hydrogen generation. Readers would find a critically examined, and comprehensive account of research in the area, along with challenges at one end. Different roles of QDs such as photosensitizer, co-catalyst, and photocatalyst have been highlighted and the influence of different preparation methods viz., photo-deposition, precipitation and wet impregnation on morphology, size of photocatalysts as well as H2 generation are discussed in detail. Apart from metal-based QDs, roles of different types of carbon-based nanomaterials like graphene, graphene oxide and carbon quantum dots for harvesting of visible light, as co-catalyst are also discussed. Finally, a conclusion on different aspects mentioned above along with future perspectives is presented.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis of quantum dots-based photocatalysts
sections.text: Diverse experimental techniques based on physical, chemical and biological methods exist for the synthesis of QDs. The size, as well as the shape of the particles, and their distributions, are directly influenced by the preparation methods and nature of precursors. This review is focused on three important chemical methods namely photo-reduction, precipitation, and wet impregnation, widely used for QDs preparation.

sections.heading: 2.1. Photo-reduction method
sections.text:
Photoirradiation of a semiconducting particle in aqueous solution instantaneously generates electron and hole pairs and continuously pumps them to surface until suitable light photons are available. These photoelectrons and holes trigger reduction-oxidation reaction spontaneously at the surface of semiconducting particles. For instance, metal ions adsorbed from aqueous/alcoholic solution on the surface of semiconductor particle undergoes reduction (metal ions (M+n) to metallic species (M0)) by accepting ‘n’ number of electrons depending on their valencies. Photocatalyst of different morphologies like nanorods, nanotubes, nano-sheets, and octahedron can be doped with one or more
metals by photo deposition preferably in the inert gas atmosphere (Fig. 2). Deposition of metallic silver or platinum on TiO2 surface by light irradiation is a common practice in photocatalyst synthesis. Chen et al. (2010), reported a scale-up synthesis of Au, Pd, Pt, Ag@TiO2 composite photocatalysts. Pt, Au, and Pd QDs with an average particle diameter less than 10 nm, and Ag nanoparticles in the range 2–20 nm diameter could be deposited on the TiO2 surface using this method.
Monodispersed copper quantum dots of 2–5 nm size were deposited on ZnO nanoparticles using hexadecylamine (HDA) as a stabilizer under light irradiation(Sliem et al., 2010). Between silver and copper decorated ZnO photocatalysts prepared by photo-reduction and liquid impregnation methods, the former displayed twice of the catalytic efficiency of latter. It has been reported that use of organo-metallic Pt precursor accelerated photo-reduction of Pt at CdS and CdSe/CdS core/ shell nanocrystals(Dukovic et al., 2008). As reported by Taing et al. (2011), even simultaneous photocatalytic reaction and photo-reduction of Ag- or Pt-nanoparticles onto the TiO2 nanoparticles (~18 nm) is possible.
Reddy et al. (Lakshmana Reddy et al., 2017d) utilized a photo-reduction method for deposition of Cu and Ag quantum dots on TiO2 nanotubes (TNT) and prepared a composite photocatalyst (Fig. 3). At first, a few grams of supporting material (TNT) was dispersed in 50mL of water:glycerol mixture containing and silver and copper ions placed in quartz reactor (capacity 185mL). Later, the reactor sealed with a rubber septum and purged with nitrogen gas and irradiated with solar light for 4 h. The colour of the solution changed immediately from white to black (Fig. 3(c)) which indicates silver and copper ions were reduced into corresponding metals in few nanaometer sizes. This method is cheap, works out well in ambient conditions, and does not require any toxic chemicals and allows a homogeneous distribution of metal at the surface without agglomeration. Simultaneous deposition of more than one metal is possible by this method. A comparison of photocatalytic H2 generation activity of various quantum dots nanocomposites prepared by photo-reduction method is given in Table 1. The comparison shows that reduced graphene oxide/CdS/MoS2 composite exhibits the highest activity. Among Ni-based catalysts, CdS/Ni displayed better performance as the quantum-sized metallic nickel on CdS facilitates the photocatalytic activity Table 1. Reddy et al. (Lakshmana Reddy et al., 2017d), explained Ag quantum dots facilitate the catalyst to harvest visible light and Cu acts as a co-catalyst leading to the improved activity.

sections.heading: 2.2. Precipitation method
sections.text:
Quantum dots have been conveniently synthesized by co-precipitation method. In a conventional route, required amount of acid (HCl, HNO3, and H2SO4) or base (NH4(OH), NaOH and KOH) solution added drop-wise into mixture of metal/chalcogenide precursor solution, as a result of chemical reaction under magnetic stirring metal chalcogenides precipitate formed. The experimental results were explained that the rate of precipitation and nature of precipitant significantly affects both particle size and morphology. In these directions, surfactants and salts such as NaCl, NaBr, NaI, KCl, KBr, KI, and CH3COONa were used. Fig. 4 shows schematic representation of quantum dots preparation using precipitation method using acid or base precipitant. Besides chemicals used in the synthesis process, continuous magnetic stirring and droplet size per minute also significantly influence the size and materials property. Finally, the precipitate is separated by ultracentrifugation or vacuum filtration.
CdS quantum dots dispersed on graphene oxide was reported by chemical precipitation method showed photocatalytic H2 generation of 314 μmol h−1 g−1 of the catalyst (Peng et al., 2012). A ternary composite photocatalyst, CdS–Al2O3/GO was prepared by the simple precipitation method, where CdS quantum dots served the role of photoharvester to enhance the activity to the tune of 633 μmol h−1 g−1 of the catalyst. A recent report on CdS QDs/ZnO/RGO nanocomposite photocatalyst showed superior H2 production performance (Wang et al., 2014a, 2014b). The performance of the catalyst was greatly influenced by the nature of precursor, choice of acid or base, surfactant and synthesis temperature. Photocatalytic H2 generation ability of various types of nanocomposite photocatalysts prepared by precipitation method is presented in Table 2.

sections.heading: 2.3. Wet impregnation method
sections.text:
Wet impregnation is a simple and widely used method in the catalyst manufacturing industries to immobilize metal, metal oxide and metal chalcogenides on the porous and non-porous support material. In brief, the support material is added into a solution containing precursor dissolved in a solvent under continuous stirring for several hours till it reaches adsorption equilibrium. Consequently, the metal ion adsorbed onto support material is separated by vacuum filtration and dried in an electric oven. The dried material loaded into tubular furnace is calcined about 400 °C for at least 4 h under (i) nitrogen (ii) hydrogen or argon gas flow in two stages by the completion of one after the other. Thus it produces metal loaded support material. Alternatively, the calcination process carried out under air or H2S gas flow facilitates metal oxides or chalcogenides formation over support material. To put in nut shell, this process ensure better surface interaction between the catalyst and support material. Various semiconductors like TiO2, ZnO, CdS, ZnS and Bi2O3 were used as support materials.
Immobilization of Ni(OH)2 on TiO2 nanotubes was carried out by a wet impregnation method as shown in Fig. 5 (Lakshmana Reddy et al., 2018). This catalyst showed a high rate of photocatalytic H2 production 47.1 mmol h−1 g−1 of catalyst. Similarly, copper QDs loaded TiO2 exhibited enhanced H2 production of 20mmol h−1 g−1 (Clarizia et al., 2014). Almeida et al. reported the synthesis of CdS QDs on g-C3N4 composites and displayed visible light induced H2 production of 1727 μmol h−1 g−1 of catalyst. An overview of comparison between QDs preparation methods i.e. photo-reduction, precipitation and wet
impregnation is summarized in Table 3.

sections.heading: 3. Different roles of quantum dots in photocatalysis
sections.text: Diversification in chemical composition and nature of QDs enables unique surface, and optical properties and they can act as (a) Photocatalyst (b) Co-catalyst and (c) Photo-harvester.

sections.heading: 3.1. Quantum dots as photocatalyst
sections.text:
Quantum dots have some unique properties such as multiple charge carrier separation, multidimensional electron flow momentum and quantum confinement useful for photocatalytic applications. Photocatalytic applications of CdSe, CdTe, TiO2, CdS, and Bi2O3 QDs have been discussed by many researchers(Hao et al., 2016; Rawalekar et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2018; Zhukovskyi et al., 2015). Recently Cooper and co-workers (Cooper et al., 2011) reported CdSe, ZnSe and ZnS quantum dots for enhanced photocatalytic water splitting. Frame and Osterloh (Frame and Osterloh, 2010) studied CdSe/MoS2 nanocomposite for photocatalytic H2 production from water under visible light irradiation and it showed a quantum efficiency of 9.2% at 440 nm. Grigioni et al. (2016), examined the effect of CdSe size on the photocatalytic H2 evolution in the presence of visible light especially with respect to fine-tuned conduction band position. Recently a nanocomposite of MoS2/WO3 used for efficient photoelectrochemical H2 production under visible light irradiation (Alves et al., 2018). A visible light active CdTe/CdS QDs core-shell material showed excellent
photocatalytic performance for H2 production (Yue et al., 2016). A simple method was adopted for the synthesis of Co3O4 QDs and showed pure water splitting performance in the absence of co-catalyst under visible light (Zhang et al., 2016a, 2016b). Nih-hybrid CdS quantum dots in glycerol and water reaction mixture have been reported for efficient and stable photocatalytic H2 performance under visible light illumination. Wang and co-workers (Wang et al., 2014a, 2014b) carried out a detailed experimental study on effect reaction variables for enhanced photocatalytic H2 production and proposed a plausible reaction mechanism as displayed in Fig. 6. As per their mechanism, initially, after absorption of light, electron transfer from the valence band to conduction band happens and the electrons migrate to Nih surface leading to reduction of H+ ions to H2 fuel. Glycerol acts as hole scavenger and further supports hydrogen production.

sections.heading: 3.2. Quantum dots as Co-catalyst
sections.text:
The semiconductor used as a photocatalyst for water splitting should fulfill the energy gap (~2.0–~3.0 eV) and band energy potential requirements, matching with oxidation and reduction potential for water splitting reaction. It is well known that co-catalyst attached to a photocatalyst forms a Schottky junction that promotes the excitons separation/transfer and suppresses the recombination. In general, the co-catalyst reduces the energy barrier required for the photocatalytic reaction to happen and Fig. 7 shows the beneficial role of co-catalyst in photocatalytic water splitting reaction. Metals such as Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Au, and Pt possess work functions of 4.71, 4.98, 5.55, 4.64, 5.10 and 5.65 eV respectively which are greater than the work function of TiO2 (4.2 eV). Hence these metals can be used to create Schottky junction
when attached to TiO2 as co-catalyst (Shokouhimehr et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2019). As the availability of noble-metals is limited in nature, and are expensive, hence non-noble-metal based materials have been also exploited. Quantum dots of CuO, ZnO, NiO, Ni(OH)2 Bi2O3, Co2P, W2P, PdS, and MoS2 are frequently used for water splitting reactions (Mishra and Adelung, 2018; Santhosh et al., 2018; Sharma et al., 2019).

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Metal quantum dots
sections.text:
Nanoparticles of transition and noble metals like Ag, Au, Cu, Pt, Pd,
Ni in quantum dots dimensions attached to semiconductor photocatalyst can serve the role of co-catalyst to improve H2 generation efficiency. A recent report by Zhang et al. explained pure water splitting using visible light active Pt–Co/g-C3N4 photocatalyst and achieved 1.2 and 0.6 μmol h−1 of H2 and O2 (Zhang et al., 2016a, 2016b). Apte et al. (2013) elaborated the synthesis of Bi QDs on glass, and it showed an enhanced photocatalytic H2 production rate of 11,541 μmol h−1 g−1 of catalyst from industrial effluent containing H2S. Xu et al. (2019), examined Ni doped CdTe hybrid nanocomposite for H2 production and proposed a mechanism as shown in Fig. 8. In this hybrid nanocomposite catalyst, Ni acts as a co-catalyst and captures electrons from conduction band and provides them for reduction to generate H2 gas.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Metal oxide quantum dots
sections.text:
Metal oxides quantum dots are more stable, less toxic and eco-
friendly and hence suitable candidates for photocatalytic H2 evolution studies. A wide range of metal oxides such as CuO, Bi2O3, Co3O4, NiO, Ni(OH)2 and WO3 was studied as co-catalysts for photocatalytic H2 evolution reaction. One of the recent reports demonstrated the higher work function and surface interaction of Bi2O3 QDs and Ag QDS on TiO2
nanotubes leading to improved H2 production rate (26.0mmol h−1 g−1cat ) (Lakshmana Reddy et al., 2017a) (Lakshmana Reddy et al., 2017b). Hu et al. (Hu et al., 2013) found enhanced photocatalytic H2 production activity of NiO QDs loaded NaTaO3 photocatalyst at an optimal loading of 3 wt% NiO; lower and higher loading of NiO than 3wt% lead to lower activity. It was also explained that charge transfer
through the interfacial barrier between NiO QDs and NaTaO3 is responsible for the enhanced activity. Presence of Ni(OH)2 quantum dots having an average particle diameter of 8.4 nm on TiO2 nanotubes found to trigger enhanced H2 production rate 12 folds higher than pristine TiO2 nanotubes(Lakshmana Reddy et al., 2018). CuO/TiO2 nanocomposite with particle size from 2 to 5.6 nm displayed enhanced and stable H2 production for 75 h under LED light irradiation (Lakshmana Reddy et al., 2017c). Zhu et al. (2019) probed a quantum dots CoxO/gC3N4 hybrid nanocomposite have prepared for visible light driven photocatalytic H2 production and claimed the existence of Type-I and Type-II heterojunctions (Fig. 9) based on the size of the metal oxide QDs which can act as co-catalyst or photosensitizer. In Type-II heterojunction, electron transfer happens from the conduction band of CoO to CB of C3N4 and holes transfer occurs from VB of CoO to C3N4; whereas in Type-I heterojunction, both electrons and holes from CB and VB of C3N4 transfer to CoO.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Metal chalcogenide quantum dots
sections.text:
Quantum dots of metal chalcogenides such as MoS2, PdS showed the co-catalyst effect for the enhanced rate of H2 production. Suneel Kumar et al.(Kumar Suneel et al., 2017), explained efficient electron transfer across the ZnO–MoS2-RGO ternary nanocomposite photocatalyst. At optimal conditions, they observed maximum H2 evolution rate of 28.6 mmol h−1 g−1 of the catalyst. A novel CdS QDs coupled graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) displayed an H2 production rate of 17.27 μmol h−1 which is nine folds higher than pristine g-C3N4 photocatalyst (Ge et al., 2012). González-Moya et al. (2016), demonstrated that pristine TiO2 nanotube does not show any activity under visible light, whereas CdS QDs decorated TiO2 nanotubes absorb light in the visible spectrum and inject electrons to the conduction band of TiO2 nanotubes which inturn provide electrons for reduction reaction to produce H2 gas. Wang et al. (X. Wang et al., 2017), explored a novel composite consisting of MoS2 QDs-Ag/Polyaniline as a visible light active photocatalyst. It showed an apparent quantum efficiency of 30.5% (λ=430 nm) besides its high stability and reusability under the tested conditions.

sections.heading: 3.3. Quantum dots as photo-harvester
sections.text:
Metallic gold and silver quantum dots exhibited unique optical properties called surface-plasmon-resonance (SPR). Here, resonant oscillation of conduction electrons happens at the interface between negative and positive permittivity of the material excited by incident light. As a result, it acts as photo-harvester and injects electron to the conduction band of semiconductor nanoparticle. Rawool et al. (2018),
reported that QDs NiO/TiO2 nano composite for enhanced H2 production rates of 2064 and 1636 μmol h−1 g−1 respectively due to the SPR effect. Tanaka et al. (2017), first reported Ni-modified Au/TiO2 for overall water splitting, where Au acts as visible light sensitizer by the surface-plasmon-resonance effect. In the presence of Ni as co-catalyst, the above system displayed 5 folds higher rate of H2 production than the Ni-free system. Lakshmana Reddy et al. (Lakshmana Reddy et al., 2017d), studied photocatalytic H2 generation via water splitting using copper and silver QDs decorated TiO2 nanotubes. The authors clarified the sensitizing role of Ag and co-catalytic role of Cu QDs based on characterization and experimental results. The bimetallic Cu, Ag deposited catalyst showed H2 production rate of 48mmol h−1 g−1cat whereas Ag-TNT and Cu-TNT catalysts showed 23.3 and 25.3mmol h−1 g−1cat , which revealed the synergistic effect of both Ag and Cu QDs on the photocatalytic activity (Fig. 10).

sections.heading: 3.4. 1Metal chalcogenide quantum dots as stable photocatalysts
sections.text:
Quantum dots of metal sulphides like CdS, CuS, Bi2S3, and MoS2 coupled with semiconductor photocatalysts have been extensively studied for photocatalytic H2 generation. (Jiao et al., 2019; Y. Liu et al., 2019a, 2019b; Ma et al., 2019; Meng et al., 2019; Shi et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2019; Zhong et al., 2019). Literature reports (Ge et al., 2012; Cao et al., 2013) showed that g-C3N4 decorated with CdS semiconductor QDs exhibited tremendous photocatalytic performance. It is due to the effective transfer of photogenerated charge carriers between g-C3N4 and QDs, which facilitates hot electron/hole separation on both parts. A mechanism for this was explained by using CdS QDs/Au/g-C3N4 nanocomposite (Ge et al., 2012) which is illustrated in Fig. 11. Cao et al. (2013), found that the CdS QDs/g-C3N4 nanocomposite exhibited ~115
folds greater H2 activity than pristine g-C3N4.

sections.heading: 4. Quantum dots carbon nanostructures in photocatalysis
4.1. Graphene quantum dots
sections.text: Graphene quantum dots (GQDs), have acquired increasing consideration as photocatalyst due to tuneable optical, electronic properties, electron reservation capability, and abundant edge defects. Moreover, GQDs used as an alternative to noble metals and metal-free co-catalyst for H2 production reactions (Tian et al., 2017). Gong et al. (2016), reported improved photocatalytic performance by GQDs/TiO2 heterojunction due to the efficient separation of electron-hole pairs. Yeh et al. (2015), reported nitrogen-doped GQDs with TiO2 for enhanced activity as shown in Fig. 12. Jeon et al., and Yang et al.(Jeon et al., 2016; Yang et al., 2017), showed GQDs modified TiO2 nanotubes for enhanced photocatalytic efficiency under UV light irradiation. To sum-up, GQDs has played a key role in enhancing the photocatalytic H2 evolution.

sections.heading: 4.2. Graphene oxide quantum dots
sections.text:
Graphene Oxide Quantum Dots (GO QDs) is also an important class of 2-D nanomaterials that shows remarkable photocatalytic properties. Due to more electron negativity of oxygen atoms than carbon, GO served as p-type material and by replacing N-containing groups it converted into an n-type (Fan et al., 2011). The larger surface area of GO QDs proved as an efficient catalyst for water-splitting without noble metal co-catalysts (Kandi et al., 2017). The n-type conductivity facilitates hot hole migration to the surface and leads to oxidation of water to produce O2 gas (Yeh et al., 2014). The main body in this QDs contained nitrogen atoms, and peripheral planes are oxygen functionalities from the consequent oxidation for influenced H2 efficacy. Further TEM images are displayed in Fig. 13(a–e) and schematic representation of the graphene functionalized nanostructures shown in Fig. 13 (f).
Replacing oxygen by nitrogen may upgrade the catalyst having both pand n-type conductivity to the graphene. The recombination of an electron-hole pair in GO is shown in Fig. 14, and the recombination of hot electron/hole occurs in the vicinity of the sp2 clusters (Lei et al., 2017). The small sp2 clusters of nitrogen doped GO QDs may assist as the interfacial junction between the p- and n-type domains distributed in the QDs. Recently Zhang and co-workers reported on the Pd–Ag/ Graphene oxide for efficient reduction from 4-nitrophenol to 4-amino phenol (Zhang et al., 2019).
The energy levels of hot electron/hole and band bending favours pand n-type domains respectively (Kumar et al., 2017; Li et al., 2016). In modified GO, the water-splitting reactions take place due to favourable band bending in the diode system as shown in Fig. 14.
The diode consists of the p- and n-type domains, connected through the sp2 clusters as an ohmic contact. Illumination on the diode system results in recombination of majority carriers at the sp2 clusters to produce useful electron-hole pairs at the semiconductor water interfaces. The band bending of the p-type domains at the semiconductor-water interfaces is analogous to Photo-system I for electron injection to produce H2. The band bending of the n-type domains at the semiconductorwater interfaces is analogous to Photo-system II for hole injection to produce O2. This overall water-splitting reaction scheme for the graphene-based photocatalyst bears a remarkable similarity to biological photosynthesis.

sections.heading: 4.3. Carbon quantum dots
sections.text:
As Xu et al. (2004), discovered carbon QDs (CQDs) are an important class of carbon materials, with varying size in the range 1–10 nm. CQDs put together the unique optical properties and electrical properties of sp2 carbon materials. CQDs are essential candidates for manipulation of high-performance photocatalysts as it can play a dual role as co-catalyst and harvester of visible light. CQDs show photo-harvester and conducting property, and they are excellent electron donors and acceptors (Wang et al., 2017a, 2017b). CQDs well favor for photocatalytic applications due to essential features like superiority in chemical stability and low toxicity. Functionalization of CQDs with other photocatalysts makes them absorb a wide range of light photons, which is very essential for photocatalysis. The CQDs serve as a reservoir for electrons to
improve efficiency by separating electron-hole pairs of TiO2 (Xie et al., 2014). Siu and co-workers reported on carbon quantum dots/TiO2 nanosheets with predominant (001) plane greatly influenced for photocatalytic hydrogen production, Fig. 15(a–d) shows TEM images for CQDs deposited on the TiO2 nanosheets large number of the quantum dots present in the nanocomposite with the average size 2–5 nm are uniformly decorated on the TiO2 (001) surface. And Fig. 15(e–f) reveals photocatalytic reaction mechanism for pristine TiO2 (001) and CQDs/ TiO2, here it was analysed that the pristine material showed lower H2 activity due to charge carrier recombination. In addition, the CQDs/ TiO2 nanocomposite showed superior photocatalytic activity owning to CQDs that are better exciton separation (Sui et al., 2019).

sections.heading: 4.3.1. Carbon quantum dots as a harvester of visible light
sections.text:
CQDs can effectively improve the photocatalytic H2 evolution efficiency by coupling with photocatalysts. For example, Yu et al. (2014), prepared CQDs/TiO2 composite and improved performance of TiO2 under UV–visible light irradiation. Here, the CQDs acts as a harvester of visible light and injects electrons to CB of TiO2 for reduction reactions. Recently, Martindale and co-workers reported superior H2 production system using CQDs/Ni photocatalyst (Martindale et al., 2015). The composite photocatalyst showed 398 μmol h−1 of catalyst for H2 whereas in the absence of CQDs the Ni catalyst alone did not indicate
any activity. It is proposed that CQDs are acting as the first harvester of visible light for photocatalytic activity.

sections.heading: 4.3.2. Carbon quantum dots as co-catalyst
sections.text:
CQDs can also act as co-catalyst in water splitting reactions where it can trap electrons from photocatalyst and performs the reduction of H+
into H2. Recently, Wang et al. (2018), demonstrated CDS/g-C3N4 nanocomposite for enhancing the photocatalytic H2 evolution. The g-C3N4 alone showed only 0.51mmol g−1.h−1 of catalyst for H2 production, while the CQDs deposited g-C3N4 shows 2.34mmol g−1.h−1 of catalyst which is four folds higher than pristine material. The better photocatalytic performance of CDS/g-C3N4 could be mainly explained by enhancing the separation of electron-hole pair and restraining the recombination of electrons and holes in the hybrids. As illustrated in the left bottom of Fig. 16, CDs acts as the electron acceptors. Under visible light illumination, the photo-induced electrons excited from g-C3N4 can easily transfer to CDs, which could efficiently enhance the separation of electron-hole pairs, and thus exhibited the better ability of photocatalytic H2 evolution. Furthermore, the interaction between CDs and gC3N4 was also an important aspect for its photocatalytic performance, which could improve the charge transfer ability of CDs/g-C3N4. During the preparation process of g-C3N4/CD hybrids, glucose and urea were firstly mixed and re-crystallized, and the hydrogen bonding between the hydroxyl groups of glucose and the amino groups of urea made an even distribution of glucose in urea matrix. Then in the process of the thermal polymerization of urea and the carbonization of glucose, the close connections between CDs and g-C3N4 were formed(Jiao et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2019; Yeh et al., 2014). This close connection could enhance the charge transfer and prevent the recombination of electronhole at their interface. Additionally, during the heating process, the released ammonia gas produced by the thermal polymerization of urea could produce a protective gas to prevent the CDs from burning. As a result, the CDs/g-C3N4 hybrids with uniform CDs distribution and close interface connection could be easily prepared by this method. In addition many earlier reports on g-C3N4 and other materials nanocomposites, recently Rathi et al. (2018), examined TiO2/g-C3N4 nanorods modified co-catalyst Cu–Ni hybrid nanostructures for efficient photocatalytic production. Recently Tavakkoli et al. (2017), studied platinum deposition on the single-walled carbon nanotubes for superior
photocatalytic activity. Recent reports on g-C3N4 based photocatalyst for H2 produced is summarized in Table 4.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and future perspectives
sections.text: This review accounts for efficient hydrogen production and its utilization as a promising alternative fuel for future applications. Development of energy efficient photocatalyst that can utilize solar light and improve the performance through surface-interface properties in top-priority this field. Based on our detailed literature survey, it is revealed that photo-reduction method stands top among the three chosen methods. The importance of quantum dots has been highlighted as an efficient photocatalyst to scale up the efficiency of the photocatalysts towards practical applications. Unique properties of the QDs have been stressed up, which are most important for improving the photocatalytic activity. Further, quantum dots are effectively utilized to improve the photocatalytic efficiency in three ways: as a photocatalyst, co-catalyst and photo-harvester. Quantum dots of transition metal, noble metal, certain metal oxides and metal chalcogenides having higher work function than photocatalyst served as co-catalyst for photocatalytic hydrogen production. On the other hand, Au, Ag and some metal oxides as well as metal chalcogenides served as photo-harvester through surface plasmon resonance effect. Interestingly, quantum dots of carbon, graphitic carbon nitride, graphene, and graphene oxide also serves as metal-free co-catalyst and photo-harvester. It might be concluded that though QDs-based photocatalysts show some remarkable activities, still it should be improved further in terms of efficiency and scale-up efficiency in hydrogen production. Further, band energies can be controlled by the size change in quantum dots, which gives new ways to control the response and efficiency in a multi-excitons generation as a rainbow photocatalyst for efficient hydrogen production.

metadata.abstractText: Nano-size photocatalysts exhibit multifunctional properties that opened the door for improved efficiency in energy, environment, and health care applications. Among the diversity of catalyst Quantum dots are a class of nanomaterials having a particle size between 2 and 10 nm, showing unique optoelectrical properties that are limited to some of the metal, metal oxide, metal chalcogenides, and carbon-based nanostructures. These unique characteristics arise from either pristine or binary/ternary composites where noble metal/metal oxide/metal chalcogenide/carbon quantum dots are anchored on the surface of semiconductor photocatalyst. It emphasized that properties, as well as performance of photocatalytic materials, are greatly influenced by the choice of synthesis methods and experimental conditions. Among the chemical methods, photo-deposition, precipitation, and chemical reduction, are the three most influential synthesis approaches. Further, two types of quantum dots namely metal based and carbon-based materials have been highlighted. Based on the optical, electrical and surface properties, quantum dots based photocatalysts have been divided into three categories namely (a) photocatalyst (b) co-catalyst and (c) photo-sensitizer. They showed enhanced photocatalytic performance for hydrogen production under visible/UV–visible light irradiation. Often, pristine metal chalcogenides as well as metal/metal oxide/carbon quantum dots attached to a semiconductor particle exhibit enhanced the photocatalytic activity for hydrogen production through absorption of visible light. Alternatively, noble metal quantum dots, which provide plenty of defects/active sites facilitate continuous hydrogen production. For instance, production of hydrogen in the presence of sacrificial agents using metal chalcogenides, metal oxides, and coinage metals based catalysts such as CdS/MoS2 (99,000 μmol hg) TiO2–Ni(OH)2 (47,195 μmol hg) and Cu/Ag–TiO2 nanotubes (56,167 μmol hg) have been reported. Among the carbon-based nanostructures, graphitic C3N4 and carbon quantum dots composites displayed enhanced hydrogen gas (116.1 μmol h) production via overall water splitting. This review accounts recent findings on various chemical approaches used for quantum dots synthesis and their improved materials properties leading to enhanced hydrogen production particularly under visible light irradiation.
